TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Click on the “Continue” button to study the Nitrogen Cycle process occurring in the ecosystem.
Nitrogen and Oxygen are the key elements responsible for the Nitrogen Cycle process. They exist in the atmosphere as N2 and O2.
Click on the “Lightening” button to study the atmospheric nitrogen fixation process.

The enormous energy liberated during the lightening process breaks down the nitrogen molecules existing in the atmosphere and enables the Nitrogen atoms to combine with oxygen in the air forming Nitrates (NO3-).
Click on the “Assimilation” button to study the conversion of nitrates into other compounds that can be taken up by the plants for their metabolic activities.
The nitrates (NO3-) first enter into the soil.
From the soil, the plant absorbs the nitrates (NO3-) with the help of their root hairs. The NO3- is then incorporated in the plants as Nitrogenous compounds (N*).

Click on the Ammonification button to study how the nitrogen in the air is converted into nitrogenous compounds such as Ammonia and Ammonium ions with the help of nitrogen fixing bacteria existing in the plant root nodules and soil.
Select an appropriate organism for continuing the process.

When the N2 enters the soil, nitrogen fixing bacteria in the root nodules of the plants takes up and converts it into ammonia, NH3. It is then incorporated in the plants as Nitrogenous compounds (N*).
Similarly the nitrogen fixing soil bacteria convert the nitrogen into ammonium ions and incorporated in the plants as Nitrogenous compounds (N*).
Click on the Nitrification button to study the steps involved in converting the ammonia/ammonium ions into nitrates.
Select an appropriate organism for continuing the process.
The ammonia (NH3) / ammonium ion (NH4+) in the soil is first converted into nitrites (NO2-) with the help of nitrifying bacteria (Genus Nitrosomonas).
The nitrites (NO2-) are then converted to nitrates (NO3−) by the nitrifying bacteria (Genus Nitrobacter).
The plant absorbs the nitrates (NO3-) with the help of their root hairs and it is then incorporated in the plants as Nitrogenous compounds (N*).
Click on the Denitrification button to study the steps involved in converting nitrates to nitrogen gas.
Select an appropriate organism for continuing the process.
The live bacteria in the deep soil use nitrates as an alternative to oxygen for respiration, which may ultimately gets converted to molecular nitrogen.
Through a series of steps, the Nitrogen is incorporated in the plants as Nitrogenous compounds (N*).
Click on the Herbivores button to study how the living organisms use the nitrogenous compound for their metabolic activities.
The herbivores such as rabbits consume the grass and plants in the land area.
While consumption, the nitrogenous compounds stored in the plants reaches into the herbivores and thus become a part of their metabolism.
During the course of time, the plants will decay, releasing the stored nitrogenous compounds into the soil.
Similarly the animals also die releasing the stored nitrogenous compounds in their body to the soil.
Click on the Decomposition button to study the decomposition of nitrogenous compounds for replenishing nitrogen in the atmosphere.
Through the series of microbial action the nitrogenous compounds are converted to nitrates and the cycle continues in the ecosystem.
Finally the Nitrogen and Oxygen compounds are replenished in the ecosystem.
